verses.kjv: And it came to pass in the month Nisan, in the twentieth year of Artaxerxes the king, that wine was before him: and I took up the wine, and gave it unto the king. Now I had not been beforetime sad in his presence.
verses.ct: In the month of Nisan, during the 20th year of King Artaxerxes, wine was set before him. I picked up the wine and served it to the king. I had never appeared unhappy in his presence before.

verses.kjv: Wherefore the king said unto me, Why is thy countenance sad, seeing thou art not sick? this is nothing else but sorrow of heart. Then I was very sore afraid,
verses.ct: So the king asked me, "Why do you look so sad? You're not ill, so this must be deep grief in your heart." I became extremely frightened.

verses.kjv: And said unto the king, Let the king live for ever: why should not my countenance be sad, when the city, the place of my fathers’ sepulchres, lieth waste, and the gates thereof are consumed with fire?
verses.ct: I replied to the king, "May the king live forever! How could I not look sad when the city where my ancestors are buried lies in ruins, and its gates have been destroyed by fire?"

verses.kjv: Then the king said unto me, For what dost thou make request? So I prayed to the God of heaven.
verses.ct: The king asked me, "What is it you're asking for?" So I prayed to the God of heaven.

verses.kjv: And I said unto the king, If it please the king, and if thy servant have found favour in thy sight, that thou wouldest send me unto Judah, unto the city of my fathers’ sepulchres, that I may build it.
verses.ct: Then I said to the king, "If it pleases the king, and if your servant has earned your trust, would you send me to Judah, to the city where my ancestors are buried, so that I can rebuild it?"

verses.kjv: And the king said unto me, (the queen also sitting by him,) For how long shall thy journey be? and when wilt thou return? So it pleased the king to send me; and I set him a time.
verses.ct: The king, with the queen sitting beside him, asked me, "How long will your trip take, and when will you come back?" The king was willing to send me, so I gave him a specific timeframe.

verses.kjv: Moreover I said unto the king, If it please the king, let letters be given me to the governors beyond the river, that they may convey me over till I come into Judah;
verses.ct: I also said to the king, "If it pleases the king, could I have letters addressed to the governors of the province west of the Euphrates, so they will grant me safe passage until I reach Judah?"

verses.kjv: And a letter unto Asaph the keeper of the king’s forest, that he may give me timber to make beams for the gates of the palace which appertained to the house, and for the wall of the city, and for the house that I shall enter into. And the king granted me, according to the good hand of my God upon me.
verses.ct: "Also, a letter to Asaph, the manager of the royal forest, so he will provide me with timber to construct beams for the gates of the fortress near the temple, for the city wall, and for the house where I will stay." The king granted all of this, because God's gracious hand was on me.

verses.kjv: Then I came to the governors beyond the river, and gave them the king’s letters. Now the king had sent captains of the army and horsemen with me.
verses.ct: When I arrived before the governors of the province west of the Euphrates, I presented the king's letters to them. The king had also sent army officers and cavalry with me.

verses.kjv: When Sanballat the Horonite, and Tobiah the servant, the Ammonite, heard of it, it grieved them exceedingly that there was come a man to seek the welfare of the children of Israel.
verses.ct: When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard about this, they were deeply disturbed that someone had come to work for the well-being of the people of Israel.

verses.kjv: So I came to Jerusalem, and was there three days.
verses.ct: I arrived in Jerusalem and stayed there for 3 days.

verses.kjv: And I arose in the night, I and some few men with me; neither told I any man what my God had put in my heart to do at Jerusalem: neither was there any beast with me, save the beast that I rode upon.
verses.ct: Then I got up during the night — just me and a few men with me. I hadn't told anyone what my God had placed on my heart to do for Jerusalem. The only animal with me was the one I was riding.

verses.kjv: And I went out by night by the gate of the valley, even before the dragon well, and to the dung port, and viewed the walls of Jerusalem, which were broken down, and the gates thereof were consumed with fire.
verses.ct: I went out at night through the Valley Gate, past the Dragon Spring, and on to the Dung Gate, inspecting the walls of Jerusalem that had been broken down and the gates that had been destroyed by fire.

verses.kjv: Then I went on to the gate of the fountain, and to the king’s pool: but there was no place for the beast that was under me to pass.
verses.ct: Then I continued on to the Fountain Gate and the King's Pool, but the path was too narrow for the animal I was riding to get through.

verses.kjv: Then went I up in the night by the brook, and viewed the wall, and turned back, and entered by the gate of the valley, and so returned.
verses.ct: So I went up along the valley in the darkness, examining the wall. Then I turned around, came back, and re-entered through the Valley Gate.

verses.kjv: And the rulers knew not whither I went, or what I did; neither had I as yet told it to the Jews, nor to the priests, nor to the nobles, nor to the rulers, nor to the rest that did the work.
verses.ct: The officials had no idea where I had gone or what I had been doing. Up to that point, I hadn't said anything to the Jews, the priests, the nobles, the officials, or anyone else who would be involved in the work.

verses.kjv: Then said I unto them, Ye see the distress that we are in, how Jerusalem lieth waste, and the gates thereof are burned with fire: come, and let us build up the wall of Jerusalem, that we be no more a reproach.
verses.ct: Then I said to them, "You can see the terrible situation we're in — Jerusalem is in ruins, and its gates have been burned down. Let's rebuild the wall of Jerusalem so we're no longer an object of disgrace."

verses.kjv: Then I told them of the hand of my God which was good upon me; as also the king’s words that he had spoken unto me. And they said, Let us rise up and build. So they strengthened their hands for this good work.
verses.ct: I told them how God's gracious hand had been on me, and also what the king had said to me. They responded, "Let's get started and build!" So they committed themselves to this good project.

verses.kjv: But when Sanballat the Horonite, and Tobiah the servant, the Ammonite, and Geshem the Arabian, heard it, they laughed us to scorn, and despised us, and said, What is this thing that ye do? will ye rebel against the king?
verses.ct: But when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite official, and Geshem the Arab heard about it, they mocked and ridiculed us, saying, "What do you think you're doing? Are you rebelling against the king?"

verses.kjv: Then answered I them, and said unto them, The God of heaven, he will prosper us; therefore we his servants will arise and build: but ye have no portion, nor right, nor memorial, in Jerusalem.
verses.ct: I answered them, "The God of heaven will give us success. So we, his servants, will get up and build. But you have no share, no claim, and no historic right in Jerusalem."
